skill.name: writing-plans
skill.description: Structured implementation planning for multi-step development tasks. Use when you have a spec or requirements and need to break work into executable steps.
skill.summary: Structured implementation planning for multi-step development tasks. Use when you have a spec or requirements and need to break work into executable steps.
skill.author: CodingCossack

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill is a documentation-only SKILL.md file that provides planning guidelines. It contains no executable code, scripts, network calls, or shell commands. The scanner incorrectly flagged markdown backticks as shell backticks and the word 'description' as a weak cryptographic algorithm.

content.value_statement: Breaking down complex development tasks into bite-sized, verifiable steps helps developers stay focused and maintain momentum. This skill transforms specifications into executable plans with exact file paths, test code, and verification commands.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes requirements and specs to create detailed implementation plans
Breaks complex features into bite-sized 2-5 minute tasks
Generates complete test code with assertions for each task
Provides exact file paths and line numbers for modifications
Includes verification commands with expected outputs
Follows engineering principles: DRY, YAGNI, TDD, and frequent commits
limitations: Does not execute the plan - only creates documentation
Requires user to provide clear requirements or specifications
Cannot access external resources or run exploratory commands without explicit instruction
Assumes the user will follow the generated plan manually or with another skill

use_cases.title: Feature Implementation Planning
use_cases.description: A developer has a feature specification and needs a step-by-step implementation plan with tests, code changes, and commit messages for each task.

use_cases.title: Onboarding to Unknown Codebase
use_cases.description: A new team member receives a feature request and uses this skill to create a safe, incremental plan that explores the codebase and implements changes with verification at each step.

use_cases.title: Complex Refactoring Planning
use_cases.description: Before refactoring legacy code, a developer creates a detailed plan that breaks the work into test-first steps, ensuring each change is verified before moving to the next.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an implementation plan for [feature description]. The tech stack is [language/framework]. Requirements: [list requirements]. Save the plan to docs/plans/feature-name.md
prompt_templates.scenario: When you have a clear feature request with requirements

prompt_templates.title: User Story Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: I have this user story: [paste user story]. As a [user type], I want to [action] so that [benefit]. Create a TDD implementation plan. Tech stack: [stack details]
prompt_templates.scenario: When working with agile user stories

prompt_templates.title: Bug Fix Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this bug report: [describe bug]. Create a test-first plan to reproduce the issue, fix it, and verify the fix. Include exact test cases and expected behaviors.
prompt_templates.scenario: When planning bug fixes with tests

prompt_templates.title: API Integration Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plan to integrate [API/service] into our [project type]. We need to [list integration requirements]. Include handling for [error cases or edge conditions].

output_examples.input: Create a plan to add user authentication with JWT tokens to our Python Flask API.
output_examples.output:
# User Authentication Implementation Plan

**Goal:** Add JWT-based authentication to Flask API with login, logout, and protected routes.

**Architecture:** Use Flask-JWT-Extended for token management. Store tokens in HTTP-only cookies for security.

---

### Task 1: Install and configure JWT extension

**Files:**
- Modify: requirements.txt
- Modify: app/__init__.py:1-30

**Step 1: Add dependency**
```
pip install Flask-JWT-Extended
```

**Step 2: Initialize JWT in app**
```python
from flask_jwt_extended import JWTManager

jwt = JWTManager(app)
```

...

best_practices: Always read existing code patterns before writing new code to maintain consistency
Write failing tests first to define the expected behavior before implementation
Keep each task small enough to complete in 2-5 minutes and verify independently
Include exact file paths and line ranges to minimize developer cognitive load
anti_patterns: Writing plans with TODO placeholders instead of specific code examples
Skipping test code and just describing what tests should do
Creating large tasks that span multiple files or take hours to complete
Forgetting to verify that file paths and commands actually exist before the task

faq.question: Does this skill execute the plan it creates?
faq.answer: No. This skill only creates the implementation plan document. You can use the subagent-driven-development skill or parallel execution mode to execute the plan.

faq.question: How detailed are the generated plans?
faq.answer: Plans include exact file paths, specific code to write, test assertions, verification commands with expected outputs, and git commit messages.

faq.question: What if I do not have a git worktree?
faq.answer: The skill recommends using the using-git-worktrees skill first to create an isolated worktree for safe experimentation.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for any programming language?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill adapts to the tech stack detected from project files like package.json, pyproject.toml, or similar configuration files.

faq.question: What makes a good task for this skill?
faq.answer: Tasks should have clear requirements, be verifiable through tests or commands, and be completable in 2-5 minutes by an engineer unfamiliar with the codebase.

faq.question: How do I hand off a plan for execution?
faq.answer: After saving the plan, choose between subagent-driven execution (fast iteration in one session) or parallel session execution (batched execution with checkpoints).
